verses.text: David spoke the words of this song to the Lord on the day the Lord delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
verses.comment: The introductory line matches the one found in Psalm 18. The phrase ‘words of this song’ follows the Hebrew closely.

verses.text: He said: The Lord is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer,
verses.comment: Retains the parallel wording with Psalm 18.

verses.text: My God is my rock, in whom I take refuge, my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my stronghold and my refuge, my savior; you save me from violence.
verses.comment: ‘Horn of my salvation’ is kept literal as a symbol of strength.

verses.text: I call upon the Lord, who is worthy to be praised, and I am saved from my enemies.
verses.comment: Retains the original order for clarity and literary style.

verses.text: The waves of death surrounded me; the torrents of destruction terrified me;
verses.comment: The ‘waves’ and ‘torrents’ retain the imagery from the Hebrew.

verses.text: The cords of Sheol entangled me; the snares of death confronted me.
verses.comment: ‘Sheol’ is transliterated, following standard translation for the underworld.

verses.text: In my distress I called upon the Lord; I called to my God. From His temple He heard my voice, and my cry came to His ears.
verses.comment: Preserves ‘His temple’ though it is before the temple was built, referencing God’s heavenly dwelling.

verses.text: Then the earth shook and trembled; the foundations of the heavens quaked and were shaken, because He was angry.
verses.comment: ‘Heavens’ follows the Hebrew; some versions have ‘mountains’. Kept literal.

verses.text: Smoke rose from His nostrils, and devouring fire from His mouth; coals were kindled by it.
verses.comment: Personification is kept literal from the Hebrew idioms.

verses.text: He bowed the heavens and came down; thick darkness was under His feet.
verses.comment: Literal translation for ‘bowed’ as in ‘bent’ or ‘lowered’.

verses.text: He rode on a cherub and flew; He was seen on the wings of the wind.
verses.comment: ‘Cherub’ left as Hebrew ‘kerub’; ‘He was seen’ follows 2 Samuel text differing slightly from Psalms.

verses.text: He made darkness coverings around Him, gathering of waters, thick clouds of the skies.
verses.comment: Maintains the poetic parallelism.

verses.text: Out of the brightness before Him, fiery coals blazed.
verses.comment: ‘Fiery coals blazed’ matches the vivid imagery of Hebrew.

verses.text: The Lord thundered from heaven, and the Most High gave His voice.
verses.comment: ‘Most High’ (Heb. ‘Elyon’) preserved.

verses.text: He sent out arrows and scattered them; lightning, and routed them.
verses.comment: Literal translation of military imagery.

verses.text: Then the channels of the sea were seen; the foundations of the world were laid bare, by the Lord’s rebuke, by the blast of the breath of His nostrils.
verses.comment: ‘Channels’ follows the common rendering for Hebrew word.

verses.text: He reached down from on high, He took me; He drew me out of many waters.
verses.comment: Literal phrase ‘drew me out of many waters’ kept.

verses.text: He delivered me from my strong enemy, from those who hated me, for they were too mighty for me.
verses.comment: No interpretive addition; stays close to Hebrew.

verses.text: They confronted me in the day of my disaster, but the Lord was my support.
verses.comment: ‘Support’ matches literal sense of Hebrew.

verses.text: He brought me out into a spacious place; He rescued me, because He delighted in me.
verses.comment: ‘Spacious place’—literal, Hebrew ‘wide place’.

verses.text: The Lord dealt with me according to my righteousness; according to the cleanness of my hands He rewarded me.
verses.comment: ‘Cleanness of my hands’ as a metaphor for innocence.

verses.text: For I have kept the ways of the Lord, and have not wickedly departed from my God.
verses.comment: Faithful to Hebrew structure.

verses.text: For all His commandments were before me, and from His statutes I did not turn aside.
verses.comment: Literal translation kept, no interpretive insertions.

verses.text: I was blameless before Him, and I kept myself from guilt.
verses.comment: ‘Blameless’ is a common rendering for ‘tamim’. ‘Guilt’ translates ‘iniquity’.

verses.text: Therefore the Lord has rewarded me according to my righteousness, according to my cleanness in His sight.
verses.comment: ‘Cleanness in His sight’ is direct from Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: With the faithful You show Yourself faithful; with the blameless man You show Yourself blameless;
verses.comment: Care was taken to keep the repetition of the original.

verses.text: With the pure You show Yourself pure, but with the crooked You show Yourself shrewd.
verses.comment: ‘Crooked’ and ‘shrewd’ closely follow the Hebrew adjectives.

verses.text: You save a humble people, but your eyes are on the haughty to bring them down.
verses.comment: ‘Humble’ is direct for ‘afflicted’, ‘haughty’ for ‘lofty’—standard translations.

verses.text: For You are my lamp, O Lord, and the Lord lights up my darkness.
verses.comment: ‘Lamp’ instead of ‘light’, following Hebrew.

verses.text: For by You I run against a troop, by my God I leap over a wall.
verses.comment: ‘Troop’ and ‘wall’ as literal images for warfare/victory.

verses.text: This God—His way is perfect; the word of the Lord proves true; He is a shield for all who take refuge in Him.
verses.comment: Faithfully follows order and parallelism.

verses.text: For who is God, but the Lord? And who is a rock, except our God?
verses.comment: No interpretive paraphrase.

verses.text: God is my strong refuge; He makes my way blameless.
verses.comment: ‘Strong refuge’ retained from Hebrew.

verses.text: He makes my feet like the feet of a deer and sets me on my high places.
verses.comment: ‘Deer’ instead of ‘hind’, modernized.

verses.text: He trains my hands for war, so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
verses.comment: ‘Bow of bronze’ as in ancient metallurgy.

verses.text: You have given me the shield of your salvation; your help makes me great.
verses.comment: ‘Help’ is a rendering for ‘gentleness’/‘condescension’—unclear in Hebrew.

verses.text: You gave a wide place for my steps under me, and my feet did not slip.
verses.comment: ‘Wide place’ = security, literal Hebrew.

verses.text: I pursued my enemies and destroyed them, and did not turn back until they were consumed.
verses.comment: Parallel with Psalm 18.

verses.text: I consumed them and crushed them, so that they did not rise; they fell under my feet.
verses.comment: Literal translation of combat imagery.

verses.text: For You equipped me with strength for the battle; You made those who rise against me fall under me.
verses.comment: Kept close to the order of Hebrew.

verses.text: You made my enemies turn their backs to me, those who hated me, and I destroyed them.
verses.comment: ‘Turn their backs’ is literal idiom.

verses.text: They looked, but there was none to save; to the Lord, but He did not answer them.
verses.comment: Exact parallel with Psalm.

verses.text: Then I beat them fine as the dust of the earth; I crushed them and stamped them down like the mud of the streets.
verses.comment: ‘Mud of the streets’ is more literal than ‘mire of the streets’.

verses.text: You delivered me from the strife of my people; You kept me as the head of the nations. People I did not know serve me.
verses.comment: ‘Strife of my people’ follows ‘contentions of my people’ in Hebrew.

verses.text: Foreigners come cringing to me; as soon as they hear of me, they obey me.
verses.comment: ‘Cringing’ is literal rendering of Hebrew root.

verses.text: Foreigners lose heart and come trembling out of their strongholds.
verses.comment: Stays close to Hebrew.

verses.text: The Lord lives, and blessed be my rock, and exalted be my God, the rock of my salvation,
verses.comment: ‘The Lord lives!’ literal acclamation.

verses.text: the God who gave me vengeance and brought down peoples under me,
verses.comment: ‘Vengeance’ as in ‘vindication’—no euphemism.

verses.text: who brings me out from my enemies; you lift me up above those who rise against me; you delivered me from the violent man.
verses.comment: ‘Violent man’ matches Hebrew.

verses.text: For this I will praise you, O Lord, among the nations, and sing praises to your name.
verses.comment: Direct Hebrew order kept.

verses.text: Great salvation He brings to His king, and shows steadfast love to His anointed, to David and his offspring forever.
verses.comment: ‘Steadfast love’ for ‘chesed’, kept in standard form.
